title: Quickest way to hang a HUGE TV? - With magic...
description: Win the Ultimate Gaming Set Up, with VIZIOs 65 P-series Quantum X TV, their Elevate Sound bar, a PS5, and more! Enter to win here:  Education is the most important thing a person can do. And the most valuable thing a person can get. I hope these super huge VIZIO TV's will help these title one schools in my area. TV's are a good way to transmit information. Educational videos are sometimes more informative than in person instruction. And I'm super glad VIZIO let me help out with their project.  *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Green Pry tool:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: Three...two...one... So behind me I have 10 massive TV's from Vizio that we're going to be installing in 10 very lucky elementary schools in my area. Title 1 schools. Vizio reached out and asked if I could help with a huge holiday project and I'm totally on board for that. So huge thanks to Vizio for sponsoring this video. Now all I need to do is sneak in the schools and install the TV's Santa-Rig-Everything style. Let's get started. [Intro] So if you want a large TV that gets the job done with 4K and HDR but doesn't break the bank, you know, it's reasonably priced, Vizio is probably what you are looking for. Vizio has a few different series of TV's and the ones we're going to be installing in the elementary schools today are their V-series TV. And the V-series is still 4K and HDR, and is good for gaming...not that the students are going to be gaming. The V-series does have the IQ active processor and the V-series gaming engine. But if you're a serious gamer you might want to upgrade to this guy which is Vizio's M-series which has everything the V-series has but also variable refresh rate, AMD freesync, and both series have auto gaming mode...which if you're a gamer you probably know what those mean. Now let's get these installed. [Music] Our first TV is going to be installed at Sharon Elementary which is home of the Seagulls. A title one school that's pretty close to where I live. So we're going to start off in a library, and it's going to go right here where a really old fireplace used to sit. The TV they have right now in the library is one of these guys. I don't know if any of you are old enough, but you have to change the channel, you have to put it on channel 3 in order to get a VCR to play. It's ancient technology and it's high time it got upgraded to something new. Coming around here to the back, it's pretty much almost unusable at the moment because there's not even like any HDMI ports or anything. It's just these old red, white, and yellow RC cables. So here we go. This is going to be one of the easier installs we do today just because we're putting it on the feet. But one trick of doing that is just taking the Styrofoam that already came with the TV, putting it back in the box, laying the box flat, and then putting the TV back on top of it so there's room to put the little feet. And there we have it. A 70 inch 4K HDR 10 plus TV. This TV is quite a bit better than what they had before, and with the HDMI ports they can actually use it. It's got chromecast built in, along with Apple Airplay too, so you can stream stuff directly to the TV directly from any Android or IOS devices. Personally I think all of the world's problems can be solved through education. So I'm super happy that the kids here at this school get a brand new awesome piece of technology that will help facilitate their learning. Whether they're using it for announcements or watching educational YouTube videos, TVs are just a great way to communicate information and help that learning process. This is definitely one of the easiest TVs we've had to set up so far. I think the next couple are quite a bit more difficult, pretty high off the ground even, but I'm pretty happy with where we're at. So the second TV we're installing is inside of this cafeteria, where actually, it's going to be interesting, we're putting it a little higher up on this wall so it stays out of the way, and we're putting it on a swing arm mount so it can actually sit at an angle so everyone in the cafeteria can watch the morning presentations. And back here tighten these up. And there it is, mounted in the corner and ready for the whole auditorium of people eating lunch to watch it. Onto the next one. [Music] Just pulled into the elementary school. The Bonneville Broncos are getting a 70 inch TV and this one also should be pretty interesting. It's going next to their stage. [Music] There we go, another install done. This one is in their large cafeteria as well as right next to the stage. [Music] Congratulations to the Windsor Wildcats, you have a TV mounted in your lunchroom. Alright Cherry Hill Mustangs, today we are taking your tiny 1080p TV and giving you a brand new 4K. And would you look at that. Already done. [Music] New school, and this one should be interesting. This is the Westmore Wildcats, and instead of this little tiny computer monitor looking thing over here, they want a massive TV right below their sign. So we're going into a block and we're hanging it pretty high above this hallway. It should be fun. So finding the center of the wall is pretty easy. There are 13 bricks across so we just found the center of that middle brick. Easy enough. Plus the mounts you can slide back and forth. But, going up and down, we want to make sure that we don't cover up the sign when people are walking through the door. We want to make sure the TV doesn't hang down below into the hallway...cuz we know how kids are and they want to reach up and grab it. Doing some math and some measurements we got it all. But I did notice one thing that's probably going to bug a couple people...If we're looking at the whole sign it looks great except right here under the A is white. None of the other letters have white on them. And now every kid walking through this hallway is going to notice the white part of the letter A and I apologize for nothing. [Drilling sounds] Honestly this might be my favorite one yet, centered right there with the sign they can see it when they walk in through the front door. Westmore Elementary has now been upgraded to 4K. [Music] Inside the Orem Jaguar's Junior High, I think they need a new TV just about there. Jaguars have a brand new 4K Vizio smart TV. Greenwood Gators, you guys have a new TV in your conference room. I hear the Mount Mahogany Rams want a new TV. [Riley] Not bad. [Christmas music] [Zack] After installing TVs all day we are down to our last two units and they are going in this school right here: Westmore Elementary. This has been a super fun project and I'm glad Vizio asked me to be on board. Hanging this one should be interesting. And another TV is up in the cafeteria. This time we had an audience. This whole room is full. The last TV we're going to install is one of Vizio's M-series. The M-series can do everything that the V-series can, but it has a little bit more color and is better for gaming. This has Vizio's pro gaming engine with AMD freesync and variable refresh rate. This one's not going on a wall, it's just going to sit here in a classroom and kind of be like a mobile unit. They do have a few rules that are interesting. I saw this one back here. Huge thanks to Vizio for letting me be a part of this project. They have made thousands of kids happy today. If you want a big TV that gets the job done without being crazy expensive, I'll leave some links down in the video description for the TVs we hung up today. We did the 70 inch V-series in a lot of the larger rooms, and the 65 inch M-series here in the classroom. Vizio is an American company that makes TVs and sound bars, so I'll leave those links down in the video description. If you have any questions leave them down in the comments. Come hang out with me on Instagram and Twitter. And thanks a ton for watching, I'll see you around.
